channel.title: Comments on: Color maps from colorbrewer

item.title: By: Tetiana
item.dc:creator: Tetiana
item.description: Thank you for your answer. I was thinking maybe something using pm3d and additional column for color code? Anyway, if you come up with a solution, please share it with us!
item.content:encoded:
Thank you for your answer.
I was thinking maybe something using pm3d and additional column for color code?
Anyway, if you come up with a solution, please share it with us!

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description:
Hi Tetiana.
This is indeed a feature that is missing, and I'm afraid it is not straight forward to achieve as gnuplot normally cannot know beforehand how many lines you will plot. Maybe there is a way to write a function or a script that gets as input the number of lines and the color palette to use and generates the corresponding line styles on the fly. I will think about it.
item.content:encoded:
Hi Tetiana.

This is indeed a feature that is missing, and I’m afraid it is not straight forward to achieve as gnuplot normally cannot know beforehand how many lines you will plot.
Maybe there is a way to write a function or a script that gets as input the number of lines and the color palette to use and generates the corresponding line styles on the fly. I will think about it.

item.title: By: Tetiana
item.dc:creator: Tetiana
item.description:
First of all, thank you very much for this amazing web-site. I've learned so many amazing new things!
I have a question about using palettes for line colours. Number of lines in my plots is varying (from a few to a few tens), but I want them to be rainbow-coloured, with the first line always being red, and the last line always being purple. By defining line styles, I am able to achieve the desired result only for as many lines as there are styles. Could you help me with this?
item.content:encoded:
First of all, thank you very much for this amazing web-site. I’ve learned so many amazing new things!

I have a question about using palettes for line colours. Number of lines in my plots is varying (from a few to a few tens), but I want them to be rainbow-coloured, with the first line always being red, and the last line always being purple. By defining line styles, I am able to achieve the desired result only for as many lines as there are styles. Could you help me with this?

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description:
Hi Jasmine.
I'm afraid you have to specify your problem a little bit more precise: * what do you mean by "colorful vectors"? Using the <a href="./../../manpage-gnuplot-4-6/index.html#Q1-1-177" rel="nofollow">vector plotting style</a> with different colors? * are the three categories separated by the columns or have you three categories in all of the columns?
item.content:encoded:
Hi Jasmine.

I’m afraid you have to specify your problem a little bit more precise:
* what do you mean by “colorful vectors”? Using the vector plotting style with different colors?
* are the three categories separated by the columns or have you three categories in all of the columns?

item.title: By: Jasmine
item.dc:creator: Jasmine
item.description:
Thanks for the nice illustration. I have a question regarding to plotting several colorful vectors. My dataset consists of 4 columns in which I have three categories . All categories should be plotted as vector but in different colors. Could you advise me how I could do that in gnuplot?
Thanks
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for the nice illustration. I have a question regarding to plotting several colorful vectors.
My dataset consists of 4 columns in which I have three categories .
All categories should be plotted as vector but in different colors.
Could you advise me how I could do that in gnuplot?

Thanks

item.title: By: Anna Schneider
item.dc:creator: Anna Schneider
item.description: Hi Thadeu -- The colorbrewer scales are designed to be perceptually linear. But you can take the exponential of your data then apply the linear colormap.
item.content:encoded: Hi Thadeu — The colorbrewer scales are designed to be perceptually linear. But you can take the exponential of your data then apply the linear colormap.

item.title: By: Thadeu Penna
item.dc:creator: Thadeu Penna
item.description: Nice tip! How could I use the colormap in a log scale ? I mean, the colors changing faster at the top of scale. Congratulations for such nice site.
item.content:encoded: Nice tip! How could I use the colormap in a log scale ? I mean, the colors changing faster at the top of scale. Congratulations for such nice site.
